However, the suggestion to 'relax and enjoy themselves' implies a different kind of pressure, like stress or anxiety, which is unrelated to the physical dangers of deep-sea diving. sentence: I recently purchased a German Shepherd and I can't understand a goddamn thing it says. Would it be easier to teach it English or to learn German?

sentence: If yesterday was 2015 and today is 2016, is tomorrow going to be 2017?
label: False Cause
baseline explanation: The sentence falsely assumes a direct causal link between days and years—suggesting that if yesterday was last year and today is this year, then tomorrow must be next year. While this can be true on New Year's Eve (like December 31 to January 1), it's a special case. Normally, days and years are correlated through the calendar, but a day passing doesn’t cause a year to pass. The logic breaks when applied outside that one exception.
candidate explanation: The logic here doesn’t make sense because the sentence seems to treat years like they change daily, which isn’t how time works. Years represent a full 12-month period, not individual days. So, if today is in 2016, tomorrow would still be in 2016 unless it’s December 31st. The assumption that tomorrow automatically becomes the next year is flawed.
rationale: The candidate pinpoints the exact same false causal link between a day passing and a year passing, notes the December 31→January 1 exception, and doesn’t introduce or omit any aspect of the baseline critique.

sentence: If a watched pot never boils, can't we use that principal and all go to the ice caps to stare at them?
label: Contextomy, Nominal Fallacy
baseline explanation: The phrase 'a watched pot never boils' is a metaphorical expression meaning that time seems to pass more slowly when you are waiting for something to happen. It is not meant to be taken literally. Applying this saying to the melting of ice caps is a misinterpretation, as staring at them won't actually stop them from melting. The logic here is flawed because it takes a figurative expression and tries to apply it literally to a real-world situation.
candidate explanation: Hey, so the logic here doesn't really hold up. The saying 'a watched pot never boils' is just a figure of speech meaning things seem to take longer when you're waiting impatiently. It’s not a real scientific principle you can apply to something like ice caps melting. Staring at the ice caps won’t stop or slow down the melting process since it’s driven by climate and temperature, not our attention.
rationale: Both explanations point out that 'a watched pot never boils' is a figurative expression not meant to be applied literally to ice caps, and that staring won’t affect the melting process. They identify exactly the same logical flaw without adding or omitting aspects.

sentence: If Albert Einstein was so great then why is he dead

sentence: Why does soap slowly disappear over time as I use it? Do you have my soap? Why does everything leave me?

sentence: Why is it that dogs go "wolf" but wolves go "owwwwwwwl" and owls go "who?"

So when an owl says "who," the joke is that it’s naming another animal instead of itself. It’s a playful bit of wordplay, not logic—owls don’t literally ask questions, and animal sounds don’t reflect names, even if it sounds like they do.

The sentence tries to connect these sounds as if they’re intentional or related, but they’re just human interpretations of animal noises with no real logical link.
rationale: Score 2: The Candidate identifies the same flaw as the Baseline—the conflation of animal sounds with words/names and the fact that the pun is just playful wordplay, not logical reasoning, without adding or omitting any core aspect.

sentence: If 700,000 people die in hospitals every year. Why don't we close down these hospitals and prevent those deaths?

candidate explanation: The logic here doesn’t hold up because hospitals aren’t the cause of those deaths; they’re often the last place people go when they’re already critically ill or injured. The deaths aren’t due to hospitals existing—they’re due to diseases, accidents, or other health issues that hospitals are trying to address.
rationale: Candidate matches the baseline’s identification of the correlation-versus-causation fallacy (hospitals aren’t causing deaths; they treat the already ill) and notes that closing hospitals would increase deaths by removing access to care—exactly the same points as the baseline.

sentence: Why is the sun so hyped? At least the moon gives a bit of light at night. The sun only shines in the daytime, when it's light anyway.

sentence: If guns don't kill people, people kill people, does that mean that toasters don't toast toast, toast toasts toast?

sentence: If we only use 10% of our brain at a time, but we share 98% of our DNA with chimps, but our bodies are 70% water, why isn't our brain 6.86% swimming chimps?

sentence: If people are so concerned about global warming, why not start another cold war?

sentence: My high school teacher told me that every time I have a cigarette, it takes a minute off of my life, but it takes me 5 minutes to smoke a cigarette. Does this mean I achieve a net gain of 4 minutes on my life?

sentence: Why hasn't a "minute" been standardized yet? 10 minutes on a microwave is an eternity, but 10 minutes snoozing my alarm is an instant.

sentence: In the 1990s, I could easily lift a TV with a 27" inch screen. Now I can easily lift a TV with a 65" screen. How much stronger am I going to get?

sentence: I've been living in a nuclear family for most of my life. Will radiation poisoning ever become an issue?

baseline explanation: The sentence commits an equivocation fallacy by confusing the microwave "smoking" (malfunctioning or burning something) with the act of smoking tobacco. It humorously assumes the microwave can be “educated” about the dangers of lung cancer, like a person. The real issue is that the microwave is literally emitting smoke—a fire hazard—yet the speaker treats it like a misbehaving human instead of fixing or replacing it.
candidate explanation: Hey, I get the humor here, but the logic doesn’t hold up. A microwave is just a machine—it can’t learn or understand health risks like lung cancer. The smoking is likely a mechanical issue, not something you can fix by ‘educating’ it. You’d be better off troubleshooting the problem or getting it repaired!
rationale: The candidate pinpoints the same equivocation: that “smoking” is a mechanical malfunction not tobacco use, and that you cannot “educate” a microwave as if it were human—instead you must repair it.

sentence: My programming teacher told me to use a loop to print "Hello world" 10,000 times. My printer is running out of paper. Please send help.
label: Equivocation
baseline explanation: The word 'print' is being used in two different contexts here. In programming, 'print' typically means to display text on a screen, not to physically print on paper. The confusion arises from interpreting 'print' in the context of a physical printer, which is not what the programming teacher intended.
candidate explanation: The logic here doesn’t add up because 'printing' in programming usually means displaying text on a screen, like in a console or terminal, not physically printing on paper. So, running a loop to print 'Hello world' 10,000 times wouldn’t affect a printer or use paper—it’s just a misunderstanding of the term 'print' in this context.
rationale: Score: 2. Both explanations identify the same single flaw—the ambiguity of the term ‘print,’ conflating on-screen output in programming with physical printing on paper—and they address the identical part of the argument (the loop printing 'Hello world' 10,000 times).

sentence: I just slipped and now have nasty cuts on my arms and legs. I heard that salt cures meat. How much salt do I apply to the open wounds in order for them to heal properly?
label: Equivocation
baseline explanation: The sentence uses the word 'cures' in two different contexts: preserving meat and healing wounds. These are not the same thing. Salt is used to preserve meat by drawing out moisture, but it doesn't mean it will heal cuts on the skin. Applying salt to wounds would actually be painful and harmful, not healing.
candidate explanation: Hey, I get where you're coming from, but the logic here doesn't hold up. Salt is used to cure meat by drawing out moisture and preventing bacterial growth, which preserves it. However, applying salt to open wounds won't help them heal—in fact, it would likely cause a lot of pain and could irritate or damage the tissue further. Wound healing requires cleaning, protection, and sometimes medical attention, not preservation techniques like curing meat.
rationale: Candidate explanation identifies the same equivocation on the word “cures” between meat preservation and wound healing, notes salt’s moisture-drawing preservative role versus its painful, harmful effect on wounds, matching the baseline exactly.

sentence: If we'd all stop calling cancer cancer, nobody would have cancer.

baseline explanation: The sentence assumes that the name 'cancer' is what causes the disease, which is not true. Simply changing what we call it doesn't affect the existence or reality of the disease itself.
candidate explanation: This doesn't make sense because changing the name of something doesn't change the reality of it. Cancer is a disease, and not calling it 'cancer' won't make it disappear or stop affecting people. The problem isn't the word; it's the actual illness.
rationale: Both explanations identify the identical flaw: that changing the name of the disease doesn’t alter its existence or nature.

sentence: If a picture is worth one thousand words, how many is a picture of one word?

baseline explanation: The sentence misinterprets the saying 'a picture is worth a thousand words,' which is a metaphorical expression suggesting that images can convey complex ideas quickly and effectively. It then improperly transposes this idea by trying to apply it literally to a picture of a single word, which doesn't make sense because the original saying isn't meant to be taken literally or broken down mathematically.
candidate explanation: The logic here doesn’t hold up because the saying 'a picture is worth a thousand words' refers to the idea that a picture can convey a complex message or story, not a literal word count. Asking about a picture of one word misinterprets the metaphor, as it’s not about counting individual words but about the depth of meaning a picture can express.
rationale: Both explanations identify the same flaw: treating the metaphor 'a picture is worth a thousand words' as literal word counting and thus misapplying it to a picture of one word.

baseline explanation: The sentence is based on a false premise because it incorrectly assumes that percentages of genetic similarity and group composition can be simply added together. Humans are not 98% chimpanzee; rather, they share about 98% of their DNA with chimpanzees, which is not the same as being '98% chimpanzee.' Additionally, the idea that 25% of astronauts are chimps is factually incorrect. Even if it were true, you cannot add percentages in this way to determine a new percentage of 'chimpness.'
candidate explanation: The logic here doesn’t add up because percentages from different contexts can’t just be combined like that. The '98% chimpanzee' likely refers to genetic similarity between humans and chimps, while '25% of astronauts are chimps' seems to imply a portion of astronauts are actual chimpanzees. Adding them to get '123%' doesn’t make sense—percentages don’t work that way, and you can’t exceed 100% in this kind of context. It’s mixing unrelated ideas.
rationale: Score: 1 — The candidate correctly identifies the core logical flaw of illegally adding percentages from different contexts (genetic similarity vs actual composition) but omits the baseline’s point that the 25%-chimpastronaut claim is factually incorrect and doesn’t explicitly note the false premise of that statistic.

The speaker is taking this expression literally, which distorts its original meaning. The fact that the pot boiled is not surprising or noteworthy, as it naturally happens when water is heated, regardless of whether it is being watched.
candidate explanation: Hey, the logic here doesn’t really hold up. Watching a pot doesn’t cause it to boil—boiling happens due to heat, not observation. The old saying ‘a watched pot never boils’ is just a figure of speech about patience, not a scientific principle. So, there’s nothing groundbreaking to publish here; it’s just a normal event.
rationale: Candidate captures both the literal misinterpretation of the metaphor “a watched pot never boils” and the point that boiling is due to heat and not observation, and notes the event is not surprising.

baseline explanation: The sentence uses a play on words by taking 'wisdom teeth' literally, as if they provide wisdom or education to the other teeth. This is a nominal fallacy because 'wisdom teeth' is just a name and doesn't imply any actual wisdom or educational role. The false premise is the assumption that teeth can be 'educated,' which is not true, as teeth don't have the capacity for education or wisdom.
candidate explanation: Hey, the logic here doesn’t add up because the sentence plays on the word 'wisdom' as if it means intelligence or education for the teeth. In reality, wisdom teeth are just a specific set of molars, and their removal has nothing to do with the 'knowledge' or function of other teeth. It’s a funny mix-up of literal and figurative language!
rationale: Both explanations identify the same nominal fallacy of taking 'wisdom teeth' literally to imply educational capacity in teeth, noting the play on words between literal and figurative meaning. The candidate’s aside about removal is a minor side remark and does not alter the core shared flaw.

sentence: My play-doh says 3-5 years on the label, but I managed to eat it in under 30 minutes, do I have a genetically superior digestive system?
label: False Premise, Equivocation
baseline explanation: The sentence humorously misreads '3–5 years' on the Play-Doh label as the time it should take to consume, rather than the recommended age range. It also runs with the false premise that Play-Doh is meant to be eaten, creating a joke by mixing up safety guidelines with personal achievement.
candidate explanation: Hey, the logic here doesn’t add up. The '3-5 years' on the Play-Doh label likely refers to the recommended age range for kids to play with it, not how long it takes to eat or digest. Eating it in 30 minutes doesn’t mean your digestive system is superior—it just means you ate something that’s not meant to be food. Plus, Play-Doh isn’t safe to eat, so this isn’t a good way to test anything about your body!
rationale: Score 1: The candidate matches the baseline in noting the misreading of “3–5 years” as consumption time rather than age range and the false premise that Play-Doh is meant to be eaten, but adds a new point about testing your digestive system which is not in the baseline.

The logic doesn't hold up because the phrase 'money doesn't grow on trees' is a metaphor meaning money isn't easily obtained, while bank 'branches' refer to physical offices, not literal tree branches. The two uses of 'branch' are unrelated, so the question creates a false connection.
rationale: Both explanations identify the equivocation on “branches” (tree limbs vs. bank offices) leading to a false analogy and therefore capture the same logical flaw and aspect of the argument.

sentence: If I bury my lava lamp, will it become a magma lamp? How will I know?
label: Nominal Fallacy, False Analog, Equivocation
baseline explanation: The joke plays on geological terminology, where lava is molten rock above ground and magma is the same material below ground. By suggesting that burying a lava lamp turns it into a magma lamp, it applies scientific logic to a novelty object, as if the lamp’s name literally reflects real lava. But a lava lamp is just a decorative item with wax, not actual molten rock. The humor comes from taking the name literally and mixing earth science with household decor for an intentionally absurd result.
candidate explanation: Hey, the logic here doesn’t really hold up. A lava lamp is just a decorative item with liquid and wax that moves when heated—it’s not actual lava. Burying it won’t turn it into anything related to magma, which is molten rock deep in the Earth. It’s just a play on words, not a real transformation. You’d know because nothing would actually change about the lamp; it’d just be underground.
rationale: Score 2: Both explanations identify the same logical flaw—that the term “lava lamp” is taken literally as molten rock versus magma when buried, whereas in reality it’s just wax and liquid—without adding or omitting any core points.

sentence: Is this big lighter lighter than a little lighter even though it’s bigger because it’s more lighter?

sentence: is a light year further in a leap year?

rationale: Both explanations identify the exact same flaw: confusing a distance unit (‘light year’) with a time/calendar unit (‘leap year’), and both point out that they are unrelated and cannot affect one another.

sentence: If the 2 major components of human blood are red blood cells and white blood cells, why isn't human blood pink?

sentence: If the James Webb Space Telescope can see things as they were millions of years in the past, why don't we point it at the Earth to take photos of dinosaurs?

In reality, the telescope observes distant objects whose light has taken millions of years to reach us, allowing us to see them as they were in the past. This doesn't apply to Earth, as we cannot observe Earth's past in the same way because we are not observing light that has traveled from Earth over millions of years.
candidate explanation: Hey, so the idea here doesn’t quite work because the James Webb Space Telescope sees into the past by looking at light from super far away objects, like distant stars or galaxies. That light took millions of years to reach us, so we’re seeing those things as they were back then. But Earth is right here, so the light we see from it is current, not from millions of years ago. Pointing the telescope at Earth wouldn’t show us dinosaurs—it’d just show us the planet as it is now.
rationale: The candidate pinpoints the identical flaw—that JWST only sees past light from distant objects due to light-travel delay and cannot show Earth’s ancient past because Earth’s light is essentially current—without adding or omitting any core element from the baseline.

sentence: People keep saying "If it's stupid but it works, it isn't stupid", but people at my work are still stupid. Is this an example of a paradox?
label: Contextomy, Equivocation
baseline explanation: The sentence takes the saying 'If it's stupid but it works, it isn't stupid' out of context. The saying implies that an action or idea that seems foolish but achieves its goal isn't truly foolish. However, the speaker is applying this saying to people, not actions or ideas, which distorts its original meaning and intent.
candidate explanation: Hey, so the logic here doesn’t quite add up. The saying 'If it’s stupid but it works, it isn’t stupid' means that something might seem dumb, but if it gets results, it’s actually smart in a way. The sentence, though, just assumes people at work are stupid without connecting it to whether their methods work or not. So, it’s not really a paradox—just a misunderstanding or misapplication of the saying. A paradox would involve a real contradiction, but here it’s more like the point is being missed.
rationale: Score: 2. Both the Baseline and Candidate explanations identify the same flaw: the saying is taken out of context and misapplied to people rather than actions or ideas that 'work.'

sentence: Are slugs just snails that got hit hard in the 2008 housing crisis?

It draws a false analogy between economic hardship and biological traits, using the similarity between slugs and snails to create a clever but illogical connection.
candidate explanation: This sentence doesn’t make logical sense because it mixes up biology with an economic event. Slugs and snails are different types of mollusks—slugs don’t have external shells, while snails do. The 2008 housing crisis was a financial collapse that affected people’s homes and finances, not animals or their physical traits. So, connecting slugs to the housing crisis is just a funny metaphor, not a real explanation.
rationale: Candidate pinpoints the same false analogy between an economic event and biological traits—treating a snail’s shell like a house and joking slugs lost theirs in the 2008 housing crisis—without adding or omitting any core flaw.

sentence: Roughly 30% of all traffic fatalities are caused by drunk drivers. This means that 70% are caused by sober drivers. Why are we still allowed to drive sober?
label: False Premise
baseline explanation: The sentence twists the stats to suggest that sober drivers are more dangerous simply because they’re involved in more total accidents, ignoring that they vastly outnumber drunk drivers. It plays on a false premise that more incidents equals more risk per person, leading to a sarcastic but flawed conclusion.
candidate explanation: Hey, the logic here doesn’t add up. Just because 70% of traffic fatalities involve sober drivers doesn’t mean sober driving is the problem. There are way more sober drivers on the road than drunk ones, so naturally, more accidents will involve them. The real issue is the disproportionate danger of drunk driving, not sober driving, which is why we focus on preventing impaired driving.
rationale: Both explanations identify the same core fallacy—ignoring base rates (more sober drivers leads to more accidents) and thus wrongly equating total incidents with individual risk. The candidate doesn’t omit or distort this point.

sentence: When I mute my TV or a YouTube video, where does all the sound go?

candidate explanation: Hey, the logic here doesn’t quite add up because sound isn’t a physical thing that ‘goes’ somewhere. When you mute a TV or video, you’re just telling the device to stop playing the audio through the speakers. The sound data is still there in the file or broadcast, but it’s not being converted into actual sound waves. So, there’s no ‘place’ the sound disappears to—it just isn’t being output.
rationale: The candidate identifies the exact same flaw—that sound isn’t a physical thing that ‘goes’ somewhere when muted and muting simply stops wave production—without adding or omitting any core points from the baseline.

Making the pool smaller would make the number of 'pools' of gold seem higher, but the physical quantity of gold stays the same. So, unfortunately, this wouldn't solve global poverty since it doesn't create more wealth or resources.
rationale: Score 2: The candidate identifies the same two core flaws as the baseline—the mistaken belief that changing pool size creates more gold (it merely changes the unit of measurement without increasing physical quantity) and the erroneous idea that this would solve global poverty.

sentence: Why the big fuss over nuclear, gas, or coal energy? Can't we just have power plants that run off of electricity?
label: False Premise
baseline explanation: The sentence assumes power plants can simply run on electricity, ignoring the fact that power plants are what generate electricity in the first place. It creates a circular idea by skipping over the need for a primary energy source like nuclear, gas, or coal.
candidate explanation: The logic here doesn't add up because power plants are the ones that generate electricity, not run on it. Suggesting they run off electricity is like saying a chef should cook with already-made food—it skips the step of how the energy is actually produced. We need sources like nuclear, gas, or coal to create that electricity in the first place.
rationale: Score: 2. Both explanations identify the same circular reasoning flaw: they assume power plants run on the electricity they produce and omit the need for a primary energy source like nuclear, gas, or coal.

sentence: If food only has a certain shelf life, why don't we just set it all on the floor?
label: Nominal Fallacy
baseline explanation: The sentence misunderstands the term 'shelf life' as if it literally means food must be placed on a shelf. 'Shelf life' actually refers to the duration food remains safe and suitable for consumption, regardless of where it is stored. Placing food on the floor doesn't affect its shelf life in the way the sentence implies.
candidate explanation: The logic here doesn't add up because shelf life refers to how long food stays safe to eat, not where it's stored. Putting food on the floor wouldn't extend its shelf life—it might even make it spoil faster due to dirt or pests. The question mixes up the concept of 'shelf life' with the physical idea of a shelf, which isn't relevant to the food's expiration.
rationale: The candidate correctly identifies the core flaw (misunderstanding “shelf life” as literal storage) but adds an extra claim about food spoiling faster on the floor due to dirt or pests, which the baseline does not mention.

sentence: If I flip a coin 1,000,000 times, what are the odds of me wasting my time?
label: Begging the question
baseline explanation: The question pretends to seek a statistical probability, but the real answer is built into the action itself: if you're flipping a coin a million times, you've already wasted your time. The humor comes from posing a mathematical question while ironically proving the point through the act itself—a perfect example of begging the question fallacy.
candidate explanation: The logic here doesn’t make sense because the question assumes there’s a calculable probability for 'wasting time,' which is subjective and not a measurable outcome like heads or tails. Odds apply to specific, defined events, not personal feelings or vague concepts like wasting time.
rationale: Score: 1 — Both explanations note that assigning a probability to “wasting time” is invalid, but the baseline labels it as a begging-the-question fallacy built into the action, while the candidate omits that and instead frames it as a category error about subjectivity vs measurability.

sentence: In America, someone is shot every 15 seconds. How is that person still alive?
label: Equivocation
baseline explanation: The sentence plays on the ambiguity of 'someone', making it sound like the same person is shot every 15 seconds, which creates a humorous misunderstanding.
candidate explanation: The logic here doesn’t add up because the sentence implies it’s the same person being shot every 15 seconds, which is obviously impossible since a person couldn’t survive that. In reality, the statistic means different people are being shot at that frequency, not one individual repeatedly.
rationale: Candidate matches the baseline by pinpointing the same ambiguity of “someone” – that it misleadingly suggests one person is shot every 15 seconds rather than different people.
